newsitem.title: CHINA: China managing forex reserves not for profit.
newsitem.headline: China managing forex reserves not for profit.

text.p: China's management of its foreign exchange reserves was not aimed at making a profit due to the central bank's cautious approach, the Financial News said on Friday.

Operation of the foreign exchange reserves was an important part of China's monetary policy, the newspaper quoted Zhou Xiaochuan, director of the State Administration of Foreign Exchange (SAFE), as saying.

The central bank must consider the policy benefits of managing its reserves to support other macro-economic policies and macro-economic controls, Zhou, who is also deputy president of the People's Bank of China, the central bank, said.
China has adopted policies to use its foreign exchange more effectively and the rise in the reserves was expected to be slow, Zhou said but gave no further details.
China's foreign exchange reserves have soared to $105 billion at the end of 1996, the largest in the world after Japan, from $21.2 billion at the end of 1993 and $73.56 billion at the end of 1995.
